case: A 54-year-old Black with a history of aortic stenosis and travel to South America presents with subacute progressive dyspnea, intermittent fevers, a cough that produces pink sputum, orthopnea, and unintentional weight loss. They are found to be febrile, hypoxemic, tachypneic, and tachycardic.
differential: Infective endocarditis with possible septic pulmonary emboli
Acute decompensated heart failure due to worsening aortic stenosis
Pulmonary edema secondary to cardiac dysfunction
Tuberculosis (pulmonary or miliary, considering travel and weight loss)
Parasitic lung infection (e.g., strongyloidiasis, schistosomiasis) acquired in South America
Pneumonia (bacterial, including atypical organisms or aspiration)
Pulmonary embolism (possibly septic or bland, considering fever and hypoxemia)
Pulmonary hemorrhage syndrome (e.g., due to vasculitis or infection)
Malignancy (primary or metastatic lung cancer)
HIV-related opportunistic infection (if immunocompromised and risk factors present)

differential: Infective endocarditis (potentially with septic emboli to the lungs)

Malignancy (primary lung cancer or metastatic disease with superimposed infection)
